question: What does the Drain (DRN) boundary condition simulate in a groundwater model? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. DRN boundaries simulate outflow points that discharge only when the groundwater head is above the drain elevation.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. A DRN boundary can only discharge groundwater and will not discharge if the groundwater head is below the drain elevation.

question: Under what condition does a DRN boundary stop discharging water? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. Outflow stops when groundwater head is below or equal to the drain elevation, or if conductance is zero.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Outflow is zero when the groundwater head is at or below the drain elevation and/or when conductance is zero.

question: What distinguishes the DRN boundary from the General Head Boundary (GHB)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. DRN boundaries are one-directional with an outflow cutoff at a specified elevation. GHBs are fully head-dependent and bidirectional.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. DRNs differ from GHBs in both the possible direction of flow and in the ability to cut off flow when the groundwater head falls below a specified elevation.

question: Which of the following is required to calculate flow at a DRN boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The determination of outflow from a DRN requires drain elevation, groundwater head, and drain conductance — not recharge.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. The recharge rate is not relevant to calculating outflow at a DRN boundary, but all of the other parameters listed are needed.
